Award.AwardTitle: The Emergence of Uncertainty Monitoring from Two to Three Years of Age

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Individuals' ability to recognize when they know something, when they do not, and when they are unsure is critical for everyday functioning. To operate effectively in day to day activities, individuals must realize when they need to seek out additional information in order to avoid acting on faulty or insufficient information. An important question is how young children develop the ability to assess their own knowledge and how they learn to recognize and act on their own uncertainty. This project investigates the emergence of this ability in 2- to 3-year-old children.

Previous research indicates that children as young as three years of age recognize when they are likely to be wrong in answering a question. They avoid answering questions to which they do not know the answer, express low confidence in their responses, and request further information. Even toddlers exhibit behaviors that suggest they are tracking their own knowledge states, hesitating when their knowledge is limited and looking confident when they have relevant information. However, it is not clear if these indicators reliably reflect the accuracy of toddlers' knowledge, and whether they contribute to later emerging abilities to introspect on how well they know. In this project, Dr. Simona Ghetti will address this question, investigating the developmental emergence of these abilities. The study investigates the hypothesis that toddlers' behaviors (e.g., hesitation) and their rudimentary awareness of their states of ignorance (e.g., captured by such statements as 'I don't know') are developmental precursors of the ability to overtly introspect on uncertainty. Using a longitudinal design, the investigator will explore how these precursor behaviors at age 2 relate to measures of the ability to introspect on uncertainty at age 3.

This research will provide new insight into the emergence of introspection, which will be beneficial in educational settings. Findings from the proposed research may help identify early cues to uncertainty that could signal to educators the need to provide additional information, and might promote the development of age-specific procedures to enhance young children's ability to monitor their own knowledge states.

POR.DRECONTENT:
If you ask a 2-year-old to complete a puzzle she has played with before, she will likely grin with satisfaction as she puts it together again. If you instead give her a novel, complicated toy, she may give you a quizzical look and perhaps solicit your help to figure out how the toy works. Toddlers commonly respond to their daily experiences with behaviors that seem to match those of older children and adults: They look confident when they have the information they need, but hesitate when they don?t know enough. These behaviors are frequent but, prior to this research, we did not know whether they were meaningful indicators of toddlers? knowledge and whether they played a role in children?s emerging ability to recognize and introspect on their own mental states of ignorance or uncertainty.

In this research, we asked whether toddlers? behavioral responses ranging from apparent decisiveness to hesitation are developmental precursors of the ability to overtly introspect on uncertainty. To address this question, we first had 2-year-olds complete experimental tasks that required them to make easy and difficult perceptual decisions. They had to identify a target, such as an animal, from two partially occluded pictures that were either similar (making it harder to find the correct one) or dissimilar (making it easier to do so). As expected, toddlers were less accurate in similar trials and they responded more slowly when they made a mistake compared to when they responded accurately. We then used formal decision models (i.e., drift diffusion models) to gain a better understanding of toddlers? response times and discovered that toddlers accumulated evidence more slowly during similar trials. Moreover, we analyzed their eye movements and found that toddlers took longer to settle the gaze on the selected image on inaccurate responses, and switched their gaze between response options more frequently on inaccurate and similar trials. Finally, an exploratory analysis of our video recordings of the experimental sessions showed that the most difficult trials were also the ones in which toddlers were most likely to turn to the experimenter for help and state or sign ?I don?t know.?

Overall, 2-year-olds responded cautiously to uncertain situations by slowing down and collecting disambiguating information. These behaviors seem integral to the experience of uncertainty, and suggest that even toddlers may begin to experience uncertainty in the same way and for the same reasons as older children and adults. To establish a link between these early behaviors and later capacity to introspect on uncertainty, we reassessed the same toddlers when they were 3-years of age. At that time, they completed a perceptual decision task, that was similar to that completed at 2-years of age, but that also required children to report how confident they felt in their answers. We found evidence that eye gaze transitions between response options at age 2 predicted children?s ability to report higher confidence for correct compared to incorrect answers. Taken together, these findings suggest that when toddlers face situations requiring decisions with uncertain outcomes, they not only respond appropriately by taking extra time and seeking additional information, but they also learn to recognize the most informative cues to uncertainty and learn to map those cues to subjective feelings, and those subjective feelings to their verbal labels.

Overall, this research contributes to building a comprehensive theory of metacognition by probing its emergence during a developmental period that has been largely neglected by metacognitive research.  Findings from this research might promote the development of age-specific procedures that enhance young children?s ability to pay attention to and report on their current mental states.
